p: A potential link between the intensity of selection on variation at Alox15 and changes in winter snowpack could also explain why we did not detect selection at the same gene in the SS transect. Tamias alpinus populations in the Southern Sierra are fixed for ancestral alleles at all but one of the outlier YNP SNPs, suggesting that these populations may lack genetic variation at Alox15 that is putatively adaptive in YNP. Moreover, SS T. alpinus populations are currently found above ~3200 meters—above the elevation range showing the largest allele frequency shifts in YNP—and overall snowpack has been more stable in the southern Sierra during the last century [ 59]. Though speculative, these scenarios help illustrate how evolutionary responses among populations may depend on both adaptive potential (i.e., standing genetic variation) and local environmental conditions.
